items.title: Consider not curating a full custom Python code-style guide
items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:

Following coding style guidelines is extremely important especially for the reference implementations we create at the lab. But I've become increasingly reluctant to point contributors to our guideline document, due to the issues outlined below.

Given that curating our own code style guide is a time-consuming task and there are many excellent code guides out there, I wonder if it wouldn't be better to restrict our guide to:
- pointers to [PEP 8](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/) and other well-curated code style guides that match our expectations, and 
- only document the differences and short-comings we identify in those guides.

E.g.   "Do as in PEP 8, but indent with 2 instead of 4 spaces!" (for reasons XYZ ... needs less horizontal space, consistency with existing code don't want a global flag day, ...)

I'd also like to say that I find the [Google Python guide](http://google.github.io/styleguide/pyguide.html) really good and it covers most of the principles of our guide in a clearer way, and other things that I find helpful.


Regardless, we should also configure strong linters on all projects (see e.g.
https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/securesystemslib/issues/243) to enforce the code style we expect.  

--------


**Issues with the current guideline**

- unclear mix of `"` and `'` (see #4)
- Python2-centered, e.g.: use of `print` statement and `file` built-in, mention of Python 2.3 (!!) and 2.6, no mention of Python 3
- several inconsistencies between recommendations and examples, especially in the "Maximum line length" section, where the *"how it should be done"*-example has wrong line continuation indentation, unclear line break condition (neither hanging nor aligned indent, nor breaking close to 80 chars), no blank lines to separate logic, use of format operator which is advised against. Other inconsistencies include recommended but missing underscores in "Naming" section, missing whitespaces around operators in some string concat examples, etc...
- some code examples are unnecessarily comprehensive, so that the emphasis on the specific recommendation suffers (especially in "Maximum line length", or in "Never use short circuit..")
- syntax errors, e.g. `assert(x = y)`, or the incorrectly continued strings in  "Never use short circuit.."
- obsolete recommendations about subprocesses (these things are documented in in the Python reference of the subprocess module and only add clutter here) and pointers to archived Seattle code
- **important** drawbacks in our custom docstring format
  1. not Sphinx-friendly
  2. (less important) needs more vertical space than necessary

  I suggest using Google style docstring, for which there is [Sphinx extension](https://sphinxcontrib-napoleon.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#google-vs-numpy), and which needs less vertical space than the similar NumPy style, and which (just as NumPy) is also friendlier to the human eye than the standard reStructuredText Docstring Format.

  See https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/pull/369 for a recent switch to Google style docstring.

> have a legal mechanism where all developers of non-trivial amounts of project software assert that they are legally authorized to make these contributions.  The most common and easily-implemented approach for doing this is by using a [Developer Certificate of Origin (DCO)](https://developercertificate.org/), where users add "signed-off-by" in their commits and the project links to the DCO website.

TUF also uses a DCO (see their [GVOERNANCE.md](https://github.com/theupdateframework/tuf/blob/develop/docs/GVOERNANCE.md) and [CONTRIBUTORS.rst](https://github.com/theupdateframework/tuf/blob/develop/docs/CONTRIBUTORS.rst) files, they are also using [PROBOT](https://probot.github.io/apps/dco/) to enforce it on PRs).

**Current behavior**:
No such legal mechanism.

**Expected behavior**:
Maybe briefly review available options (CII mentions *Contributor License Agreement*) and implement appropriate legal mechanism.

labels.name: ITE and Spec compliance
labels.description: This relates to the 2019 efforts to match the spec and ITEs

milestone.title: in-toto 1.0
milestone.description: In-toto v1.0, see ROADMAP.md for more information

items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:
#257 adds gpg self-signature verification support, for signatures types 0x10-0x13 (certifications) and 0x18 (subkey binding signature). The added infrastructure may be used to also consider other signature types such as,
- 0x20: Key revocation signature
- 0x28: Subkey revocation signature
- 0x30: Certification revocation signature

See RFC4880 [5.2.1. Signature Types](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4880#section-5.2.1) and  [12.1.  Key Structures](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4880#section-12.1) for details about the signatures types and where in the key bundle they occur.

**Current behavior**:
Revocation type gpg signatures are ignored.

**Expected behavior**:
Handle revocation type gpg signatures, e.g. ignore revoked keys or certificates and/or warn user about them.

items.title: Rule verification false positives
items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:


The firewall like processing of artifact rules in `verify_item_rules` uses a material queue, a product queue and a generic artifact queue. If one of the sequentially processed rules can be applied successfully, the corresponding artifacts in the corresponding queue are removed.

The queues are updated in different places, e.g. `verify_match_rule` modifies the artifacts queue at the passed reference, which btw. also points to the materials or products queue in the beginning, only to override itself upon return. Other `verify_*_rule` function only return a new updated queue to override the old queue. Depending on the rule type ("match", "allow", ...) and the rule source type ("materials" or "products"), the three queues further update each other.

Besides being hard to understand the rule processing may lead to false positives, i.e. it may fail rule verification although it shouldn't. Here is one symptomatic minimal failing example:

```python
from in_toto.models.metadata import Metablock
from in_toto.models.link import Link
from in_toto import verifylib

links = {
  "item": Metablock(signed=Link(name="item",
       products={
           "foo" : {"sha256": "deadbeef"},
       }
  )),
}

rules = [
  # ALLOW does not consume anything here but cuts reference between
  # `source_artifacts_queue` and `source_products_queue`. NOTE: Without this
  # ALLOW the behavior of the rule sequence would be as expected.
  ["ALLOW", "bogus"],

  # MATCH consumes `foo` and removes it from `source_artifact_queues`
  ["MATCH", "foo", "WITH", "PRODUCTS", "FROM", "item"],

  # CREATE does not consume anything here, and overrides
  # `source_artifacts_queue` with an outdated `source_products_queue`
  # i.e. undoes MATCH from above.
  ["CREATE", "bogus"],

  # DISALLOW fails due to `foo` being in the `source_artifacts_queue` again
  # NOTE: CREATE re-establishes the reference between the two queues, thus
  # repeating the MATCH, CREATE rule sequence before the DISALLOW rule would
  # go back to expected behavior.
  ["DISALLOW", "*"]
]

verifylib.verify_item_rules("item", "products", rules, links)
```

**Current behavior**:
Rule processing implementation is unnecessarily complicated and may lead to false positives under certain circumstances.

**Expected behavior**:
Fix false positives and simplify rule processing.

items.title: Fix summary link naming
items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:
As per the [specification](https://github.com/in-toto/docs/blob/master/in-toto-spec.md#451-artifact-rules-in-sublayouts), *"when using sublayouts, the artifact rules that apply to the equivalent step [in the super-layout] are applied to the materials of the first [...] and the products of the last step of the sublayout"*.   To achieve this we [create summary links](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/v0.2.3/in_toto/verifylib.py#L1367) for sublayouts to be used for artifact rule verification in the super layout. 

To locate a link during artifact rule verification, we use its corresponding name. E.g. for some step of the super layout, whose artifacts should match the products of a sublayout, pertaining to a step `foo`, a rule could be:  `MATCH * WITH PRODUCTS FROM foo`.

However, currently we assign the [name of the sublayout's first step](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/v0.2.3/in_toto/verifylib.py#L1412) to its summary link, which besides posing a problem for match rules, is semantically inaccurate and may lead to namespace collisions (duplicate step names). 

Kudos to @aditya for pointing out that [the summary link naming seemed off](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto-golang/blob/ba65c84a773271d05c16d1d0a718e98f1bbeeee2/in_toto/verifylib.go#L554-L562). 

**Current behavior**:
- Summary links for sublayouts are assigned the name of its (the sublayout's) first step
- Artifact rule verification for layouts with sublayouts is not tested

**Expected behavior**:
- Summary links for sublayouts should be assigned the name of the corresponding step in the super-layout
- Add tests

items.title: subprocess.check_output()
items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:

We should use [subprocess.checkoutput()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.check_output) by default. Using `subprocessPopen()` without checking return codes sometimes leads to misleading errors (such as apparently malformed GPG signature packets, when actually GPG did not run as intended, and return the expected output).

This also means that we should just install [subprocess32](https://pypi.org/project/subprocess32/) by default.

**Current behavior**:

We use `subprocess.Popen()`.

**Expected behavior**:

We should use `subprocess.check_output()`.

items.title: PGP subkeys count towards threshold
items.body:
**Description of issue**:
After @vladimir-v-diaz 's review of [PR](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/pull/201#discussion_r174275398) #201, it was found that the threshold check with pgp keys can be bypassed by signing different pieces of link metadata with different subkeys.

**Current behavior**: A malicious functionary is able to bypass threshold verification by signing multiple pieces of link metadata with different subkeys on his private keyring. To do this, all the different subkeys need to be input by the project owner at the time of signing this root layout.

**Expected behavior**: Instead, any subkey and the master key signatures should count as a single signature towards the threshold.

items.title: Support path left strip when recording artifacts
items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:
Add support for left stripping artifact paths before storing them to link metadata. This could give more flexibility to functionaries and simplify writing artifact rules.

**Current behavior**:
Artifacts are recorded as full paths or relative to the current working directory from where `in-toto-run` or `in-toto-record` is executed (see [`--materials`/`--products` cli arguments](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/in_toto_run.py#L39-L46)), e.g:

```
$ in-toto-run --materials /home/foo ../bar baz  <...>
```
```
{
  _type: "link"
  materials : {
    "/home/foo": HASHDICT,
    "../bar": HASHDICT,
    "baz": HASHDICT
  }
  ...
}
```

**Expected behavior**:
```
$ in-toto-run --lstrip-paths /home/  ../ --materials /home/foo ../bar baz  <...>
``` 
```
{
  _type: "link"
  materials : {
    "foo": HASHDICT,
    "bar": HASHDICT,
    "baz": HASHDICT
  }
  ...
}
```

This change could make the (less obvious) `ARTIFACT_BASE_PATH` setting obsolete, which when used makes the artifact recording function change to that path and then look for the artifacts, passed using the `--materials/--products` arguments, relative from that path and also record them as such relative paths. (see [`runlib.record_artifacts_as_dict`](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/runlib.py#L148-L156))

items.title: Support require artifact rule

labels.name: ITE and Spec compliance
labels.description: This relates to the 2019 efforts to match the spec and ITEs

milestone.title: in-toto 1.0
milestone.description: In-toto v1.0, see ROADMAP.md for more information

items.body:
**Description of issue or feature request**:
As per the [specification](https://github.com/in-toto/docs/blame/master/in-toto-spec.md#L760) the require rule format is  `REQUIRE <pattern>` and *indicates that a pattern must appear as a material or product of this step.*

Before implementing this, we might clarify how to treat wildcards in a pattern (also see #152).

Here are some examples with suggested behavior.
- `REQUIRE foo` ... require artifact "foo"
- `REQUIRE foo*` ... require (at least one?) artifact whose name starts with "foo"
- `REQUIRE *` ... require anything? including nothing?


**Current behavior**:
Feature does not exist.

**Expected behavior**:

items.title: Provide alternatives to `settings.py`
items.body:
Changing settings in the [settings file](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/settings.py), which usually lives in some python site-packages directory, is cumbersome. 

We should provide alternative ways to configure these settings, like e.g. environment variables, rcfiles, and command line arguments (maybe all of them, in reverse order of precedence).

items.title: Revisit threshold verification
items.body:
Verifying step thresholds, i.e. enforcing a specified  amount of functionaries, to each provide a link file corresponding to a given step, happens in parts explicitly and in parts implicitly in various places throughout the final product verification, i.e. when:

1. [importing step metadata](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/1ae56cd767e60982cb273edb77e582cc821bd7f9/in_toto/models/layout.py#L171-L173)
2. [verifying step signatures](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/1ae56cd767e60982cb273edb77e582cc821bd7f9/in_toto/verifylib.py#L250-L257)
3. [verifying threshold constraints](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/1ae56cd767e60982cb273edb77e582cc821bd7f9/in_toto/verifylib.py#L969-L972)

(1) Tries to load a link file for every functionary authorized to carry out a step by looking for link files with the respective functionaries' keyid as filename infix. E.g. if a layout authorizes functionaries with keyids `A, B, C` and short keyids (`A', B', C'`) to carry out a step `foo` this function will look for `foo.A'.link`, `foo.B'.link`, and `foo.C'.link`.

Before returning the populated data structure of "keyid - link objects" pairs per step name, the function also checks if there are enough links with distinct keyid'ed names as specified in the corresponding step's threshold and raises `LinkNotFoundError` if not.

However, this function does not verify if the actual signatures correspond with the keyids in the filenames, and even less if those signatures are valid.

This happens in (2), which iterates over the "keyid - link objects" pairs as imported in (1) and verifies each link's (could also be a sublayout) signature with the key for that keyid.

Finally, (3) re-verifies if the data structure returned from (1) (which in the meanwhile has [replaced sub-layouts with summary links](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/1ae56cd767e60982cb273edb77e582cc821bd7f9/in_toto/verifylib.py#L1206)) has enough links per step to meet each step's threshold and then verifies if all links corresponding to a given step list the same materials/products.

I think we should try to make the above described "threshold verification process" more transparent. Maybe we can address this issue while dealing with #135.

items.title: Revisit signature verification
items.body:
The signature verification method of `Link` and `Layout` objects currently fails if:
- the passed key dictionary does not match the [`KEYDICT_SCHEMA`](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/securesystemslib/blob/master/securesystemslib/formats.py#L383-L386),
- the object has no signature,
- there is a signature for which no key is found in the passed key dictionary, which means that
  multiple signatures have to be verified at once (*), 
- and finally if any of the verified signatures is actually broken

@awwad has pointed out that this (*) might be [unexpected behavior](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/pull/125#discussion_r144058807).

Moreover, like this links and sublayouts that carry multiple signatures from different keys would always fail, because we always [pass only one key to the signature verification function](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/verifylib.py#L250-L257).

I think we should change this behavior and while we are at it we should better separate the following concerns:
- the actual cryptographic signature verification
- which keys are authorized to sign
  - for links and sublayouts this is defined in the corresponding step's `pubkeys` field
  - for layouts we have to assume that the key(s) passed to the verification tool are legitimate
- which keys are required to sign
  - for links this is assessed using the corresponding step's `threshold` and `pubkeys` fields, i.e. there must be `step.threshold` links and each one must have a signature, created with a distinct key from the list of `step.pubkeys`
  - for layouts I suggest we require at least one key, and if multiple keys are passed, each one of them must have a valid signature
  - for sublayouts this is somewhat harder. Maybe we should, [when recursing into (sub)layout verification](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/verifylib.py#L1073-L1084), pass a flag to disable regular layout signature verification? Alternatively, we could pass only the keys for which the sublayout carries signatures, as long as these keys are authorized in the corresponding step's `pubkeys` filed 


*Note: Please fix comments/docstrings (also in in `in_toto_sign.py`) when dealing with this issue*

items.title: Adopt move return value inside byproduct dictionary in link metadata
items.body:
The [current specification](https://github.com/in-toto/docs/blob/69c29b41f4c1fe064b5d77d61d4b268fc171bcaa/in-toto-spec.md#44-file-formats-namekeyid-prefixlink) lists the return value as part of the opaque byproduct dictionary and not as separate field. 

This change should be propagated to the [in-toto inspection command line tools](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto-inspections).

items.title: Adopt order of final product verification routines
items.body:
At some point the specification changed the order of the final product verification routines to only run the inspection commands after having successfully verified all steps' artifact rules.

IIRC, we also talked about only running an inspection command after having verified that inspection's material rules. However, the [current specification](https://github.com/in-toto/docs/blob/69c29b41f4c1fe064b5d77d61d4b268fc171bcaa/in-toto-spec.md#52-verifying-the-final-product) does not indicate that.

Note that this change has implications on the availability of matching targets to a given MATCH rule. So far we were able to match any material or product of any step or inspection, because at the time of rule verification, inspection had been executed and therefore, all link files were available.

Maybe this is something we should discuss/document in https://github.com/in-toto/docs/issues/4?

The relevant code can be found in [`verfylib.in_toto_verify`](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/verifylib.py#L1162-L1170)

items.title: Adopt replace implicit DISALLOW with ALLOW
items.body:
In https://github.com/in-toto/docs/pull/2 the implicit `DISALLOW *` at the end of each list of artifact rules (`expected_materials`, `expected_products`) was changed to an implicit `ALLOW *`.

Adopting the change might be as easy as removing [this check in the rule verification routine](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/verifylib.py#L894-L899).

The rationale for this spec change will be discussed in https://github.com/in-toto/docs/issues/4.

items.title: Adopt sublayout link metadata namespacing
items.body:
According to recent specification changes in-toto sublayout verification expects link metadata files pertaining to a sublayout to reside in a fileystem directory with the following naming scheme: 

`<SUBLAYOUT NAME>.<SUBLAYOUT OWNER KEYID PREFIX>`

**SUBLAYOUT NAME:** Name of step in superlayout that is carried out as sublayout
**SUBLAYOUT OWNER:** Functionary authorized to perform the step of superlayout that is carried out as sublayout
**KEYID PREFIX:** Left-most 8 characters of keyid

See [4.5.2 Namespacing link metadata](https://github.com/in-toto/docs/blob/69c29b41f4c1fe064b5d77d61d4b268fc171bcaa/in-toto-spec.md#452-namespacing-link-metadata) for more details

In https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/issues/6 we discussed and fixed many initial user feedback issues.
In the course of a layout tool user testing session, it was noted that when looking at stdout/stderr of the used tool (`in-toto-mock`) it was unclear if the command was executed properly or not.

Here are some general user feedback related items open for discussion and fixing:

- Colorize output
- Do something about `subprocess32` warning (seems to confuse users)

items.title: Readme could use a bit more explanation about in-toto workflow
items.body:
The [readme](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/README.md#in-toto--) explains in-toto's general purpose briefly, then starts explaining what a layout contains, without providing the few sentences that I think would help a reader understand the in-toto workflow.

In particular, I think that the last paragraph of the first section of the readme (*sorry, can't link line numbers in .md in github*) would be better with a little bit more detail. For example, I might change it to something like this:

> ### In-Toto Workflow
> in-toto requires a **project layout** that specifies the functionaries and the tasks they are supposed to perform. The project designer (((or whatever term is preferred))) creates this project layout as a sequence of individual steps, referred to as **links**, designating functionaries to be trusted for each step. The functionaries in charge of each link produce link metadata once they've completed the work in their link, and provide this metadata to (etc.....). The chain of link metadata travels with the final product, and can be validated manually by the final client or via automated tooling in, for example, a package manager.

items.title: Layout model is missing the README field.
items.body:
As of the [0.9 version of the in-toto specification](https://github.com/in-toto/docs/blob/v0.9/in-toto-spec.pdf), the Layout metadata should include an optional README field.

We need to update the Layout model to reflect this change.

items.title: Refactor artifact rules field name
items.body:
The names of the artifact rule properties of in-toto steps and inspections have been updated in the specification to `expected_materials` and `expected_products` whereas in the implementation they are still called `material_matchrules` and `product_matchrules`.

These names have to be refactored in the codebase and documentation.

items.title: Cannot find link to project's website
items.body: The README should link to the project's website.   There is also an option of adding a website to the repo by clicking on "Edit" in the repo's description.

items.title: Add connman debianization demo
items.body:
We need more real world in-toto examples! This time it's Debian.

The idea is to show how in-toto can be used to guarantee the integrity of a software project from upstream development to installation using a Debian package management tool.

Let's use our great [in-toto Connman OpenSUSE demo](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/tree/develop/demo-opensuse) as a basis.

Here are some relevant pointers:

 - Connman [Homepage](https://01.org/connman) and [Upstream Repo](https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/network/connman/connman.git/)
 - [Debian Developers' Corner](https://www.debian.org/devel/)
 - [Debian Maintainer Guide](https://www.debian.org/doc/manuals/maint-guide/first.en.html)
 - [Debian Connman Package Tracker](https://packages.qa.debian.org/c/connman.html) (with links to package site and git repo)


Additionally, this might be helpful:
 - A Debian Developer's [thoughts on supply chain security](http://madduck.net/blog/2005.08.11:rcs-uploads/)
 - A Debian [hello world package](http://wiki.opf-labs.org/display/SP/The+Hello+World+Debian+Package) and a [packaging diagram](https://danielpocock.com/autotools-project-distribution-and-packaging-on-debian) (*Note: I am not guaranteeing the freshness or relevance of those links*)

items.title: Fix metadata signatures mismatch between specs and implementation
items.body:
We have been silently accepting a minor metadata format mismatch between specs and implementation. I think it is time to fix that by choosing one or the other.

Reason for the format as specified: Adopted from TUF
Reason for the format as implemented: `is-a` relationship seemed  (from an OO perspective)  more intuitive and easier to handle than `has-a` realtionship.

**Implementation**
```python
{
  "_type": "layout" or "link",
  ... # rest of the respective properties,
  "signatures" : [
    { "keyid" : KEYID, "method" : METHOD, "sig" : SIGNATURE },
  , ... ]
}
```

**Specification**

```python
{
  "signed" : ROLE, # layout or link metadata object [**]
  "signatures" : [
    { "keyid" : KEYID, "method" : METHOD, "sig" : SIGNATURE },
  , ... ]
}

# [**] Btw. I find the term `ROLE` for the metadata type really confusing. 
# While it makes sense for TUF, # where each role corresponds to 
# an individual metadata format, it does not for in-toto, which does 
# not have the some notion of roles.
```

items.title: Add `in-toto-sign` command line utility
items.body:
in-toto `Layouts` and `Links` are both [signable](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/models/common.py#L72).

Let's add a command line utility to handle in-toto metadata signatures. Here are some functions I consider helpful:

- add signature, while keeping existing signature(s)
- replace existing signature(s) with new signature
- verify signature(s)

Feel free to add your own ideas.

items.title: Add `in-toto-keygen` utility
items.body:
Currently in-toto provides some [utility functions](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/util.py) to create (password encrypted) RSA key pairs programatically.

It would be nice to additionally have a command line utility, e.g. `in-toto-keygen`, for key creation (like a stripped down `ssh-keygen`).

Keep in mind that we might want to [drop the util module](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/issues/80) at some point and move its (updated) functionality to [securesystemslib/keys](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/securesystemslib/blob/master/securesystemslib/keys.py).

items.title: Add `in-toto-mock` command line utility
items.body:
in-toto steps are usually executed using the [`in-toto-run`](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/in_toto_run.py) command line utility, whose functionality is implemented in the according library function [`runlib.in_toto_run`](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/in_toto/runlib.py#L330-L403).

Since this command requires a signing key and a bunch of command line arguments, it would be helpful to have a stripped down variant of that command that can be used to easily mock `in-toto-run`'s metadata generation aspect, without the need to specify a key and knowing all the command line arguments. 

This is particularly interesting for in-toto's [layout tool](https://github.com/in-toto/layout-web-tool), where we ask un-experienced in-toto users to (mock) run their supply chain, so that we can create a layout using the (mock) link metadata.

Here is an example usage of the envisioned command:
```
in-toto-mock -n <step name> -- <step command>
```
The resulting link metadata `<step name>.link-mock` is not signed and records materials and products at the current working directory where the command is executed.

I think `in-toto-run`'s `--verbose` and `--record-byproducts` flags should be on by default.


UPDATE:
As mentioned above `in-toto-mock` most likely will be used to reverse generate in-toto layouts with an initial set of custom artifact rules. Therefor it might be helpful to store the full path of the current working directory in resulting mock link files.
I think for now we should only store it when running `in-toto-mock` but make it so that we can easily opt in later to also store it when using `in-toto-run`.

items.title: Clean up `for` loop in signature verification
items.body: PR #85 modified an [for loop](https://github.com/RohanBhirangi/in-toto/blob/020116a0c9b4f0867975076f8da135a18c8da99b/in_toto/verifylib.py#L245-L254) inside the signature verification routines. This for loop could be further simplified and factored out.

items.title: Coalesce signature verification in-toto verify
items.body: As it is now, there are two places that perform signature verification. Following review #77, we decided that both routines could be placed in the same place, and have the second place just verify that the signature matches the keyid prefix in the filename.

items.title: Raise exception on non-zero return of Inspection command
items.body:
`Inspection` commands defined in the layout provide the possibility to execute arbitrary commands at verification time.
Inspections, like Steps, must have rules to authorize/enforce materials and products that are recorded before and after an Inspection command is run. Currently a failing rule is the only way to make an Inspection fail the verification.
Additionally, it might be desired to simply fail verification when the inspection command returns a non-zero value.

items.title: Use parentheses in multi-line imports
items.body:
I've noticed that we are doing imports as follows:

```python
from x import y, z, \
           i
```
While this is a correct way of doing it, I'd suggest we move to the parentheses construction instead:

```python
from x import (y, z,
         i)
```
The rationale behind is that our code style (which is based on pep8) [strongly hints of using parentheses for line continuation](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/code-style-guidelines#maximum-line-length)<sup>*</sup>. [PEP8](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008/#maximum-line-length) also makes the same suggestion:

> The preferred way of wrapping long lines is by using Python's implied line continuation inside parentheses, brackets and braces. Long lines can be broken over multiple lines by wrapping expressions in parentheses. These should be used in preference to using a backslash for line continuation. 

If I recall correctly, tools such as flake or pep8 mark this as a style error....

--- 
<sub>\*Should we also consider updating the example in our style guideline? </sub>

items.title: Accept matchrule string instead of lists
items.body:
I think we should allow the rule to be written as strings. A `.split()` when parsing the rule is not very expensive, whereas a split when writing the rule somehow feels stupid. I for instance script my rules like so:
```python
material_matchrules = ["MATCH PRODUCT yadda yadda".split(), ...]
 ```

items.title: Expected command pattern instead of strict and relaxed alignment
items.body:
Currently we pass command verification upon strict (must be equal) and relaxed (must have an equal prefix) alignment of recorded command and expected command. The following examples show in what cases the alignment passes or fails.

```python
# Left command is the command recorded by toto-run.py
# Right command is the expected command defined in the layout

# Passes:
["vi", "file1", "file2"] ~ ["vi", "file1", "file2"]

# Passes with warning:
["vi", "file1", "file2"] ~  ["vi"]
["make", "install"] ~  ["make"]

# Fails:
["vi", "file1", "file2"] ~ ["make", "install"]
["/usr/bin/vi", "file1"] ~ []
["vi", "file1", "file2"] ~ ["vi", "file2", "file1"]
["/usr/bin/vi", "file1"] ~ ["vi", "file1"]
```
As one can see in above examples that semantically equal commands sometimes fail whereas syntactically  (relaxed)  equal commands can pass although they have very different semantics.

@vladimir-v-diaz brought up the idea of using match patterns. We could use [regex](https://docs.python.org/2/library/re.html) or a subset of regex like implemented by [fnmatch](https://docs.python.org/2/library/fnmatch.html). This would allow either fail or pass and get rid of the relaxed pass.

In any case command alignment does not provide strong security guarantees, since recorded commands can be easily faked using alias, symlinks or the like.

items.title: Replace ssl_crypto and ssl_commons submodules with securesystemslib
items.body:
Make in-toto use the tip of [secure-systems-lab/ssl_crypto](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/ssl_crypto) and [secure-systems-lab/ssl_commons](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/ssl_commons) as submodules.

The tip of in-toto currently uses [vladimir-v-diaz/ssl_crypto@542caed](https://github.com/vladimir-v-diaz/ssl_crypto/tree/optional-password) as crypto submodule. The common package has not been sub-modularized yet at all.

This issue can be broken down into:
 - Make sure that [secure-systems-lab/ssl_crypto](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/ssl_crypto) and [secure-systems-lab/ssl_commons](https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/ssl_commons) are up-to-date with what in-toto requires.
 - Replace package in-toto ssl_commons with submodule
 - Adapt in-toto to work with changes that were made in the submodules

items.title: Deal with (relative) artifacts path recordings
items.body:
It can occur that the directory in which `toto-run` is executed and the base of the directory to record `materials` and `products` are not the same.
Consider below directory layout and a `toto-run` to be executed in `b` and record materials  in `a`:
```shell
├─/path/to/project
          ├── a
          │   ├── bar
          │   └── foo
          └── b
# in /path/to/project/b
toto-run.py --materials ../a
```
this results in a `materials` list:
```python
materials = [
   "../a/bar" : <hash>
   "../a/foo" : <hash>
]
```
Currently  matchrules would need to add dots or double-dots in the path pattern to match the recorded artifacts. This can be circumvented by using wildcard patterns, which does not seem ideal.

Two possible solutions:
- Ignore leading dots/double dots at verification time
- Add a `base-path` command line option to `toto-run`, record absolute artifact paths, leftstrip base path from absolute artifact path before writing link metadata.

items.title: Fix MATCH rule ambiguities
items.body:
The current rule type `MATCH` uses the following language:
```
MATCH (MATERIAL|PRODUCT) <path pattern> [AS <target path pattern>] FROM <step name>
```
Currently this reads (my interpretation of the specification):
>`MATERIALS` or `PRODUCTS`, depending on the rule's second element, of a step with `<step name>` and matched by `<target path pattern>`  (if specified) or `<path pattern>` (else), must have a hash that matches the hash of a `MATERIAL` or `PRODUCT`, depending on whether the rule is in the `material_matchrules` or `product_matchrules`, of a step that matches `<path pattern>` and has not been matched by a previous rule. The rule also fails if the target path pattern does not find any artifacts.

When I and @SantiagoTorres, who came up with the language and implemented it, tried to apply these rules in real world software supply chains, we both had difficulties to express what we wanted, which IMHO indicates that the language should be clarified and freed from ambiguities.
The following (or at least most of it) should be unmistakingly clear by just reading the rule:

- **What is the match source and what is the match target?**
   rule in one of step's rule lists VS.  `... FROM <step name>`

- **What is the source artifact type and what is the target artifact type?**
   rule in `material_matchrules` or `product_matchrules`  VS. `MATCH (MATERIAL|PRODUCT)...` 

- **Should there be a target artifact for every source artifact? (currently no)**
  material_matchrule (source): `MATCH PRODUCT *  FROM target-step`
  source materials : `hash(foo) = x`, `hash(bar) = y`
  target products:    `hash(foo) = x`
  Pass?

- **Should there be a source artifact for every target artifact? (currently yes)**
  material_matchrule (source): `MATCH PRODUCT *  FROM target-step`
  source materials : `hash(baz) = x`
  target products:    `hash(baz) = x `, `hash(zap) = y`
  Fail?

- **Should the rule fail if the path pattern does not find any artifacts?**
  `MATCH PRODUCT foo ...` should probably fail if there is no product foo?
  `MATCH PRODUCT * ...` should probably not fail if there is no product?

- **Do we solely match by hash in case of wildcard patterns?**
  material_matchrule (source): `MATCH PRODUCT *  FROM target-step`
  source materials : `hash(new/path/foo) = x`, `hash(bar) = y`
  target products:    `hash(foo) = x`, `hash(baz) = y`
  
- **Can artifacts be matched more than once by different MATCH rules? Would AND, OR operators to concatenate MATCHRULES help here?**

-------

Below is a super explicit language to start the discussion. This might be exaggerated but at the same time still does not express *everything*. I don't say, maximum explicitness is a must, nonetheless implicit behavior should be defined somewhere, e.g. in the specs.

```
MATCH [ALL] (MATERIAL|PRODUCT) <source path pattern> FROM <source step name> WITH [ALL] (MATERIAL|PRODUCT) <target path pattern>  FROM <target step name>
```

items.title: Layout keys dict instead of list
items.body:
The [docstring](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/toto/models/layout.py#L63-L65) of in-toto's `Layout` as well as the [default value](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/blob/develop/toto/models/layout.py#L74) suggest that the `keys` property should be a list. This does not conform with the in-toto specification and the demo implementation. 
The correct format is `ssl_crypto.formats.KEYDICT_SCHEMA`.

Please change docstring default value, and while you are at it, add model validators and unit tests!

items.title: Add intelligent constructors for metadata classes
items.body:
Currently we use default constructors for all in-toto classes. There is a "factory-like" `read` method  which has been used in the demo so far. 

It would be useful to have intelligent constructors or factories for objects that will be created manually by the project owner, i.e. `Layout`, `Step` and `Inspection`, with the following capabilities.

- ~~Take key dictionary or key list and create key dictionary from it (Layout)~~ (wontfix)
- Take expected command in list or string format (Layout)
- Add default expiration if not specified (Layout)
- ~~Take matchrules in list or string format (Step, Inspection)~~ (wontfix, would require escaping)
- Validate passed data

items.title: Move default layout expiration date to constructor
items.body: Currently the one-month default expiration date for the layout is created in the layout's `read` method.  This should rather happen in the layout's constructor.

items.title: Use "{}".format instead of "%s" % ()
Python 3 compatibility
items.body:
The current code base is mostly Python 3 compatible. Some minor changes are required though to use `in-toto` in both Python 2 and 3. 
- Replace `print` with `print()` (cf. @SantiagoTorres's and @vladimir-v-diaz's [comments](https://github.com/in-toto/in-toto/pull/19#discussion_r84122308)

items.title: Provide easy installation and workflow instructions
items.body:
People will want to use and try toto without downloading a multi-gig virtual machine (with old code).
- Provide README.md with easy installation and instructions for a simple workflow
- Update pip requirements file

items.title: Refactor framework name 'toto' --> 'in-toto'
items.body:
We decided to rename the framework to 'in-toto' (lat. as a whole) to avoid collisions with existing software projects.
We need to refactor the code base accordingly.

items.title: Step and Inspection generalization
items.body:
Steps and Inspection are both items of the software supply supply chain defined in the layout.
Steps are performed by functionaries and correspond to one or more link metadata files, whereas Inspections are performed during toto-verification, which also produces link metadata.
Both item's link metadata is verified against the defined matchrules in a similar fashion. This bears potential for generalization.

I'm inclined to call the generic type `Item` or `LayoutItem`. Any suggestions would be appreciated.

_Note:_
@JustinCappos requested a name change for`toto-run`'s  `--name` flag which sets the name field of a link metadata file and has to correspond to a Step or Inspection name defined in the Layout. He suggested `--step` or `--step-name`. I'd like to keep it abstract for Steps and Inspection, e.g. `--item-name`.

items.title: Miscellaneous material/product (artifact) enhancements
items.body:
- Support file path wildcards for artifact flags in `toto-run` and consequently in `toto-verify`
- Re-think "./" left-stripping of paths when recording artifacts (maybe this could be done in verification instead?)
- revise `record_artifacts_as_dict` function 

Later:
- think of a more sophisticated way of recording artifacts than by passing file paths as command line arguments (this might deserve a separate ticket)

items.title: Store matchrules as Matchrule objects and not as lists
items.body:
Currently we store the list representation of `Matchrule` objects in the according `Step` and `Inspection` fields. This is a workaround that allows us to use  `attr`'s convenient `asdict` function when dumping the layout to a file. 

I suggest to [implement our own `asdict` function](https://github.com/hynek/attrs/issues/103#event-825440411) allowing us to store `Matchrules` as objects but returning their list representation instead of  their dict representation when dumping the container layout.

items.title: Use validators for models and format/schema for crypto
items.body:
We share crypto specific libraries with [the update framework](https://github.com/theupdateframework/tuf) and started off toto using TUF's format/schema validation. As we are more on the OO side than TUF, we will want to replace format/schema validation with model validators, e.g. using [`attr`'s validator](https://attrs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/api.html#validators) module.
- [ ] implement validators (the downside of `attr.validate` is that it seems to be hooked to the `__init__`, which is not ideal if we want to set attributes post-instantiation and then validate)
- [x] remove `toto/formats.py`
- [x] keep using and `toto/ssl_crypto/formats.py` for crypto specific data structures, and add where appropriate

items.title: PKI helper instead of throw-away util
items.body:
Currently we provide a throw-away `create_and_persist_or_load_key` function which served its purpose during development. 
In future we definitely want something a little more sophisticated, although PKI is not part of the toto specification.
- Add pki helper interface to create and store public/private keypairs (offer standardized format, eg. PEM) 
- Change key loading calls throughout the codebase to load keys in various formats or die
- Disable the possibility of adding the private portion of a key to the toto layout

items.title: Properly duplicate standard streams
items.body:
Currently we provide a command line flag to `toto-run` to either don't touch stdout and stderr, which is required if `toto-run` wraps interactive commands like e.g. `vi`, or to redirect and store them as byproducts to the link metadata.
Ideally we would like to duplicate the streams to allow both.
- Using a pipe won't work because processes like vi will complain
- Wrapping stdout/sterr in Python won't work because the suprocess will only take the filedescriptor and then uses it natively
- Reading from /dev/(stdout|stderr), /dev/tty is *NIX specific

items.title: Enable delegation
items.body:
Delegation is provided by defining a step in the root layout that will be represented by a toto link metadata file of type `layout` in verification.
This needs to be enabled in toto-verify/verifylib.

items.title: Add key threshold
items.body:
The layout model must support an additional `threshold` field which contains an integer indicating how many pieces of link metadata must be provided to verify this step. This field is intended to be used for steps that require a higher degree of trust, so multiple functionaries must perform the operation and report the same results.
- add field to model and model validation
- change naming scheme for link metadata files: [name].[KEYID-PREFIX].link
- add in toto-verify/verifylib

In order to verify a layout file that was signed by multiple keys we simply need allow passing multiple keys to toto-verify

items.title: "Relaxed" command alignment
items.body: Command alignment verification passes if the step command as defined in the layout and the related command as recorded by the link metadata are completely equal. If only the first `x` parameters are equal (where `x` is the minimum count of both commands) `toto-verify` should output a warning.

items.title: Verify expirationdate
items.body: @SantiagoTorres [proposed to use a `datetime`](https://github.com/toto-framework/Toto/pull/3#discussion_r83093316) object for the layout's `expires` field with a default timeout (e.g. a month). This is a good idea. Also we should check this upon `toto-verify`.

items.title: User input, output, exceptions and return values
items.body:
Meaningful `exceptions` are preferred over zero vs. non-zero return values in `verifylib` and `runlib` (this is the pythonic way). 
The command line tools `toto-run` and `toto-verify` on the other hand could catch those exceptions, print meaningful output to stderr and return zero or non-zero values.

items.title: libraryfy runlib and verifylib
items.body:
- [x] `verifylib.py` :Currently the verifylib is implemented as one long function. We should separate the single verification steps into function units that are called from the commandline tool `toto-verify.py`.
  Also, functions in verifylib should not contain log/debug/info statements but rather raise meaningful exceptions that might be caught in `toto-verify.py`
- [x] `runlib.py`
  Runlib is already split into separate functions but there is one  "call-them-all" function in runlib which should be moved to `toto-run.py`. Same as above applies for log statements here.
